https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-sap-design-system-portal-for-sap-fiori-design-guidelines-and-new-ui/ba-p/14109558

Quickly generate and deploy SAP Fiori apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

The new quick SAP Fiori application generator lets you generate an application based on SAP Fiori elements annotations and deploy the SAP Fiori UI with only a few clicks from the service binding editor in ADT.
https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/quickly-generate-and-deploy-sap-fiori-apps-from-abap-development-tools-for/ba-p/14116822

Events

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Bangalore 

The biggest SAP Fiori Innovation Day ever!
This summary highlights the key sessions, insights from our presentations, and the remarkable contributions from our local development community.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-innovation-day-bangalore-connection-gratitude-ai-and-local/ba-p/14129580

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Dallas

  •              October 17 as part of the ASUG chapter meeting
  •              Registration link opening soon - mark your calendar now

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Paris

  •              December 10
  •              Registration link opening soon - mark your calendar now

All our SAP Fiori Innovation Day events are open to customers.
If you are a partner, please let me know if you are interested in sponsoring in one or both of our locations.
I hope you can join us.

SAP TechEd

Registration is now open for both the in-person event in Berlin and the virtual event. Here are details on what you can expect.
https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/sap-teched-2025-registration-is-live-check-out-our-brand-new-hybrid/ba-p/14107573

Back issues from the past year

SAP Fiori development newsletter March 2025 (Issue #33)

SAP Fiori development newsletter January 2025 (issue #32)

entry.title: Accelerate Your AI and Innovation Journey with Expert-Guided Services from SAP
entry.content:
At SAP, we are committed to helping our customers innovate and adopt technologies quickly, effectively, and with confidence. As part of this mission, we’re excited to share a series of expert-guided services and enablement opportunities offered through the Foundational success plan designed to help you unlock the power of SAP BTP including AI, SAP Build, and SAP HANA Cloud solutions.

These offerings of Expert Guided Implementation workshops (EGI) from SAP Enterprise Support are tailored to provide hands-on support and guided experiences, helping you get started with the latest innovations while minimizing complexity and accelerating time-to-value.

Whether you're looking to innovate and improve business processes through process automations, harness the power of AI to accelerate innovations, this series has something for everyone.

The following EGI sessions will run throughout the year with quarterly updates to the schedule.

Available Services at a Glance

Topic

Service Name

Description

Vector Engine, Knowledge Graph and Generative AI

SAP HANA Cloud Multiple Model Programming using Vector Engine and Retrieval Augmented Generation

Multi-day service to help customers activate and explore the Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud, enabling large language model (LLM) integration and generative AI scenarios. Currently in pilot through the SAP ESAC program.

Joule

Support to Activate Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

2-day service to empower customers on how to fulfil the prerequisites to activate Joule to be used with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (PCE).

Development using Build Code and Joule

SAP Cloud Application Programming Development using SAP Build Code and Joule

Multi-day service to empower customers with the knowledge of CAP Development in SAP HANA Cloud. After the service, customers will know of CAP development and design in SAP HANA Cloud utilizing the SAP Business Application Studio and SAP Build Code with Joule.

SAP Build Apps

SAP Build Apps

Multi-day service to help customers adopt SAP Build Apps for low-code/no-code development, including hands-on support and best practice guidance.

Process Automation

SAP Build Process Automation

Multi-day guidance designed to help customers get started with SAP Build Process Automation, including hands-on support and best practice guidance.

Administration, Monitoring topics for SAP HANA Cloud

 

Configuration, Administration, Security and Monitoring topics for SAP HANA Cloud

Help customers with SAP HANA Cloud capabilities, key features available and admin tools for database Monitoring.

Modeling in SAP HANA Cloud

SAP HANA Cloud Modeling

Empower customers with the knowledge of Modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.

 What to expect from these services

All services are delivered by SAP experts and follow a structured, guided approach that includes:

  • Overview of the solution capabilities
  • Step-by-step technical guidance
  • Hands-on activities to accelerate learning and adoption
  • Best practices and tips for long-term success

These expert-guided services are ideal for customers looking to accelerate their transformation journey, whether you're exploring AI for the first time, expanding your use of SAP HANA Cloud, or adapting business processes with SAP Build.

How it works

  • Web session, 1-2 hours each morning where SAP expert explains the topic using training materials
  • Duration is from 2 to 5 days depending on the topic
  • Set daily schedule with pre-defined goals for each day
  • Available across different time zones and languages (topic dependent)
  • Afternoon 2-3 hours on the same day where you execute demonstrated steps within your own project, on your own SAP environment
  • During that time, you have direct access to the SAP expert delivering the workshop for guidance and support
  • Registration closes one week before the session date – sign up early!

 If you are interested in participating in these expert-guided services or learning more, simply follow the links above to register for the service.

For customers if you have issues accessing the above links, there may be an authorizations issue. Please note a one-time registration in SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required for accessing the EGI service. A detailed step-by step guide to registration can be found here.

A list of the EGI services and all other SAP BTP assets, services and content for SAP Enterprise Support customers are available through the SAP Enterprise Support Value Map program.

As you continue to innovate with SAP, we are here to support you every step of the way. These services are designed to accelerate adoption, reduce complexity, and drive outcomes so you can make the most of your SAP investments at no additional cost.

Don’t miss the opportunity to engage with SAP experts and take your next steps in AI, innovation, and automation. Let us help you fast-track your success!

Thanks and Regards,

Robert Kelly

BTP Lead Architect - SAP Enterprise Support

entry.title: Accessing S/4HANA Cloud Data via SAP Build Code on the SAP BTP Platform
entry.content:
Recently, I had the opportunity to contribute to the development of an agentic use case, where I need to fetch data from an S/4HANA Cloud system using existing OData services. This experience gave me hands-on exposure to working with S/4HANA Cloud and understanding how to integrate its data seamlessly into an external application.

In this blog post, I’ll walk you through the step-by-step process of retrieving data from an S/4HANA Cloud system using OData.

What is SAP Business Technology Platform?

SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) is SAP’s unified platform-as-a-service (PaaS) offering that provides tools, services, and runtimes for building, integrating, and extending SAP and non-SAP applications in the cloud.

What is SAP Cloud Connector?

The SAP Cloud Connector is a key component in the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) landscape. It acts as a secure bridge between your on-premise systems (like SAP S/4HANA on-prem or other internal services) and SAP BTP or cloud-based applications.

What is Destination Service?

The SAP Destination Service is a managed service on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) that simplifies and secures how your cloud applications connect to remote systems such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud, on-premise systems, or third-party APIs.

Instead of hardcoding URLs, credentials, and connection details inside your app, you create a destination configuration in BTP and refer to it in your code.

Download and Install SAP Cloud Connector

You can download the Cloud Connector compatible with your machine from the following link: https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/#cloud

                                    Fig 1. Cloud Connector download

For Windows, you can choose between the ZIP archive and the MSI installer. The ZIP archive is suitable for development use cases, while the MSI installer is recommended for productive environments, as it installs the Cloud Connector as a service on the server.

Initial Configuration 

To configure the SCC, open a browser and navigate to:
https://<hostname>:8443

Replace <hostname> with the name of the machine where the connector is installed. The port number should match the one configured during installation, by default, it is 8443.

To find the hostname of your machine, open Command Prompt and enter:
hostname

                 Fig 2. Cloud Connector Login 

Enter the default credentials (case-sensitive) and click Login:

Username: Administrator

Password: manage

Upon your first login, you'll be prompted to change the password. After updating it, select Master as the installation type and click Save.

                                                       Fig 3. Reset password for SCC

The next step is to add your BTP subaccount to the Cloud Connector.

Select "Choose Manually" to enter your subaccount details manually.

On the following screen, provide the required information about your BTP subaccount. This is necessary to establish a secure tunnel between the Cloud Connector (SCC) and your SAP BTP subaccount.

Region: The region where your subaccount was created (see the picture below).

Subaccount: Your subaccount ID (see the picture below).

Login E-Mail: The email address used when creating the BTP account.

Password: The password used when creating the BTP account.

 

                                              Fig 4. Connect BTP Sub Account to SCC

 

                      Fig 5: Cloud Connector – BTP Sub Account Registration

Once successfully added your sub account you will see the screenshot as below:

                                 Fig 6. Successful Sub Account Registration

This shows that you have successfully connected your sub account with the cloud connector.

Now its time to connect your On-Premise system.

Connecting “Cloud to On-Premise” Connection:

Connect your on-premise system to the cloud connector so that it can be access in Business Technology Platform.

Under the sub account ID in your cloud connector click on Cloud to On-Premise in the left menu and then click on ‘+’ sign to add the system.

                                    Fig 7. Add S/4 HANA Cloud System in SCC

In the pop up that open choose ABAP System as the backend type and choose protocol as HTTP.

                                    Fig 8. Add Back End system type

                        Fig 9: Define Protocol for Backend Connection

For the “internal host” use the hostname or the ip address of the ABAP system and its corresponding ICM port number.

                              Fig 10: Configuring System Host Details

The “Virtual Host” is the hostname you'll use within BTP. You can either use the default value, which matches the Internal Host, or choose a different, less identifiable name.

                               Fig 11. Configuring Virtual Host

We'll leave the “Principal Type” set to “None” for now.

                          Fig 12. Configure Principal Propagation

Select to use virtual host for “Host in Request Header”.

                         Fig 13: Selecting Virtual Host Option

Provide the SAP ABAP system name.

                                 Fig 14. Selecting ABAP System 

Check the summary and click on finish.

                                                 Fig 15. Summary

After successfully creating mapping we need to create resource which is the actual service. Click on the ‘+’ sign under the resources section.

                                                          Fig 16: Resource 

To grant the subaccount access to all services, enter /sap in the URL path and choose "Path and All Sub-Paths" under the Access Policy setting. This setup can be adjusted later to restrict access to specific resources, which is strongly advised for production environments.

                                Fig 17: Adding a New Resource

Now check the resource available and ensure that the backend system is reachable as below:

                                     Fig 18. Check for connection status

Once the system is reachable you will see the status as below:

                                    Fig 19: Verifying System Reachability

If you face some issues in reaching backend system maintain the below configurations at

“Run->drivers->Click on ok-> Go to etc folder->edit hosts”

Add the host details at the bottom and click on SAVE as an example below:

 127.54.99.98    test.com

If not able to edit copy paste in different location and then change and paste again.

Now you will be able to see the connected CC in your BTP account as below:

                                     Fig 20. Cloud Connector status in BTP

Create a Destination Service

Now lets create a destination service.

BTP (Business Technology Platform) destinations serve as configuration endpoints that define how to establish secure connections with external systems or services. Commonly used in cloud environments, these destinations facilitate communication between different cloud-based applications by specifying connection parameters like endpoint URLs, authentication methods, and additional settings. You can create and manage BTP destinations through the SAP BTP Cockpit or by using the SAP Cloud SDK. They are applicable in various use cases, including accessing external data sources, calling third-party web services, or delivering notifications to external platforms.

                                   Fig 21: Creating a Destination in SAP BTP

Maintain the below configuration details:

Name: Name of your destination

Type: HTTP / HTTPS

URL: Enter the virtual host name maintained in Cloud Connector

Authentication: Basic Authentication

User: Enter the backend username

Password: Enter the corresponding password

In the additional properties maintain the below pairs:

"WebIDEEnabled": "true"

“HTML5.DynamicDestination” :"true"

"AppgyverEnabled" :"true"

“sap-platform”:”ABAP”

“sap.build.usage”:”true”

“webIDEUsage”:”odata_gen”

“sap-client”:”000”

These parameters are mantatory in certain ways to consume the destination service via SAP Build Code.

                                            Fig 22. BTP Destination Service

Click on “Save” to save the destination and click on Check Destination to check if the connection is successful.

                                             Fig 23. Check Connection

Create a SAP Build Code Project

Now lets create a SAP Build code project. Go to Instances and Subscription and click on SAP Build Code. Hope the SAP Build code is already subscribed to your sub account.

In the SAP Build Code click on Create to create a new project.

                                    Fig 24. Create a SAP Build Code project

Click on Application -> Next -> Full Stack -> Next -> Full stack Node.JS

Enter the name of the project and click on Review to review the details and then click on Create to create the project.

Once the project is created copy paste the below code:

For demonstration purposes, I have used an example involving the retrieval and modification of Purchase Order data.

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
import os
import requests
import json
import base64

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Application Initialization
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
app = Flask(__name__)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fetching port details
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
cf_port = os.getenv("PORT")

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Getting OAuth Token
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def get_oauth_token(destination_credentials):
    oauth_url = destination_credentials['url'] + "/oauth/token"
    client_id = destination_credentials['clientid']
    client_secret = destination_credentials['clientsecret']

    data = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
        'client_id': client_id,
        'client_secret': client_secret,
    }

    headers = {
        'Content-Type': 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded'
    }

    response = requests.post(oauth_url, data=data, headers=headers)

    if response.status_code == 200:
        return response.json()['access_token']
    else:
        raise Exception(f"Failed to get OAuth token: {response.status_code} - {response.text}")

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Method to fetch records 
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def get_records(lv_dest, lv_string):
    # Get VCAP_SERVICES
    vcap_services = json.loads(os.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES"))

    # Get credentials for Destination service
    destination_credentials = vcap_services['destination'][0]['credentials']
    connectivity_credentials = vcap_services['connectivity'][0]['credentials']
    destination_name = lv_dest
    dest_token = get_oauth_token(destination_credentials)

    # Fetch destination config
    dest_url = f"{destination_credentials['uri']}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/{destination_name}"
    headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {dest_token}"}
    dest_response = requests.get(dest_url, headers=headers)
    dest_response.raise_for_status()
    dest_config = dest_response.json()['destinationConfiguration']

    #  Build full URL
    target_url = dest_config['URL'] + lv_string

    # Token for Connectivity Proxy
    conn_token = get_oauth_token(connectivity_credentials)

    # Use Connectivity Proxy (Cloud Connector)
    proxies = {
        "http": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}",
        "https": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}"
    }

    backend_user = dest_config['User']
    backend_password = dest_config['Password']
    auth_string = f"{backend_user}:{backend_password}"
    auth_encoded = base64.b64encode(auth_string.encode()).decode()

    # Headers for proxy request
    headers = {
        "Accept": "application/json",
        "Proxy-Authorization": f"Bearer {conn_token}",
        "Authorization": f"Basic {auth_encoded}"
    }

    if 'CloudConnectorLocationId' in dest_config:
        headers['SAP-Connectivity-SCC-Location_ID'] = dest_config['CloudConnectorLocationId']

    # Make the proxied request
    response = requests.get(target_url, headers=headers, proxies=proxies)
    response.raise_for_status()
    print("Status:", response.status_code)
    print("Headers:", response.headers)
    print("Body:", response.text)
    return response.json()

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Method to update a record
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
def update_record(destination_name, path, payload):
    # Get VCAP_SERVICES
    vcap_services = json.loads(os.getenv("VCAP_SERVICES"))

    # Get credentials for Connectivity and Destination service
    destination_credentials = vcap_services['destination'][0]['credentials']
    connectivity_credentials = vcap_services['connectivity'][0]['credentials']
    dest_token = get_oauth_token(destination_credentials)

    # Destination config
    dest_url = f"{destination_credentials['uri']}/destination-configuration/v1/destinations/{destination_name}"
    headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {dest_token}"}
    dest_response = requests.get(dest_url, headers=headers)
    dest_response.raise_for_status()
    dest_config = dest_response.json()['destinationConfiguration']

    #  Build full URL
    target_url = dest_config['URL'] + path

    # Token for Connectivity Proxy
    conn_token = get_oauth_token(connectivity_credentials)

    # Use Connectivity Proxy (Cloud Connector)
    proxies = {
        "http": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}",
        "https": f"http://{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_host']}:{connectivity_credentials['onpremise_proxy_port']}"
    }

    backend_user = dest_config['User']
    backend_password = dest_config['Password']
    auth_string = f"{backend_user}:{backend_password}"
    auth_encoded = base64.b64encode(auth_string.encode()).decode()

    # Headers for proxy request
    common_headers = {
        "Proxy-Authorization": f"Bearer {conn_token}",
        "Authorization": f"Basic {auth_encoded}",
        "Accept": "application/json"
    }

    if 'CloudConnectorLocationId' in dest_config:
        common_headers['SAP-Connectivity-SCC-Location_ID'] = dest_config['CloudConnectorLocationId']

    # Fetch CSRF Token and Cookies
    token_headers = common_headers.copy()
    token_headers["x-csrf-token"] = "Fetch"

    session = requests.Session()
    token_response = session.get(target_url, headers=token_headers, proxies=proxies)

    if token_response.status_code != 200:
        return token_response.status_code, token_response.text

    csrf_token = token_response.headers.get("x-csrf-token")
    if not csrf_token:
        return 403, "CSRF token not returned"

    # Send PATCH with token and cookies
    update_headers = common_headers.copy()
    update_headers["x-csrf-token"] = csrf_token
    update_headers["Content-Type"] = "application/json"

    # Use session to preserve cookies
    patch_response = session.patch(target_url, headers=update_headers, json=payload, proxies=proxies)

    return patch_response.status_code, patch_response.text

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Update endpoint (POST or GET for testing)
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/update_data', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def update_data():
    if request.method == 'GET':
        purchase_order = "12345"
        item = "10"
        update_payload = {
            "DocumentCurrency": "EUR",
        }
    else:
        if not request.is_json:
            return jsonify({"error": "Request must be application/json"}), 415

        data = request.get_json()
        purchase_order = data.get("PurchaseOrder")
        item = data.get("PurchaseOrderItem")

        if not purchase_order or not item:
            return jsonify({"error": "Missing PurchaseOrder or PurchaseOrderItem"}), 400

        item = str(item).zfill(5)  # Pad item number to 5 digits

        update_payload = {
            "OrderQuantity": 15,
        }

    path = f"/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_purchaseorder_2/srvd_a2x/sap/purchaseorder/0001/PurchaseOrderItem(PurchaseOrder='{purchase_order}',PurchaseOrderItem='{item}')?sap-client=001&$format=json" #Change the OData URL

    status_code, response_text = update_record('Destination_name', path, update_payload) #Modify Destination name

    return jsonify({
        "status_code": status_code,
        "response": response_text
    })

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fetch record endpoint
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/fetch_data', methods=['GET'])
def fetch_data():
    lv_request = get_records('Destination_name', '/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_purchaseorder_2/srvd_a2x/sap/purchaseorder/0001/PurchaseOrderItem?sap-client=001&$format=json') #Change Destination name and OData URL
    return jsonify(lv_request)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Home page
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
@app.route('/', methods=['GET'])
def home():
    lv_return = {
        "result": [
            {
                'message':  'Welcome to the homepage!',
                'Fetch_data' : 'Use /fetch_data',
                'Update_data' : 'Use /update_data'
            }
        ]
    }
    return jsonify(status='200', replies=lv_return)


# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
# Main method
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
if __name__ == '__main__':
# If the app is running locally
    if cf_port is None:
# Use port 5000
        app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000, debug=True)
    else:
# Else use cloud foundry default port
        app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=int(cf_port), debug=False)

Create a manifest.yml file and paste the below:

---
applications:
- name: data_read  #Replace with your app name
  random-route: true
  path: ./
  memory: 1028M
  buildpacks:
  - python_buildpack
  command: python backend.py  #Python file name
  services:
  - service_name_001
  env:
    PYTHON_VERSION: 3.11.10

In the manifest.yml file above, most sections are self-explanatory and have been annotated with comments. The key part to focus on is the services section. To use the configured destination service, you need to create an instance of it. This service is crucial when your application needs to interact with remote systems, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud, on-premise systems, or third-party APIs.

The destination service is bound to you app so that it can access the destination definition.

What happens behind the scene?

When you bind the Destination Service to your app:

  • BTP injects the credentials into your app's environment as VCAP_SERVICES

  • Your app code can use a destination name to resolve:

    • The target URL 

    • Authentication method (Basic, OAuth2, etc.)

    • Proxy type (Internet or OnPremise)

If you are connecting to an on-premise system, it routes through SAP Cloud Connector.

How to create a service in BTP?

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit
  • Navigate to your subaccount → Cloud Foundry environment → Space.
  • Go to the Services -> Instances section.
  • Click Create Instance.
  • Choose a Service (e.g.:
    • "Destination" for Destination Service
    • "Connectivity" for accessing on-premise systems
    • "xsuaa" for user authentication/authorization
    • "hana-cloud" or postgresql for databases
  • Choose a plan (e.g. lite, standard, etc.)
  • Enter the name
  • Click Create.

                                               Fig 25. Create a service

Alternatively you can also create a service using bash command as below:

cf create-service destination lite service_name_001 #Replace with your service name

Once the coding is complete, you can proceed with testing the functionality.

Using terminal login to cloud foundry, use the command

cf login

                                           Fig 26. Login to CF

Once the login is successful you will see the below message

                                                Fig 27. CF login

After which you can deploy your app using the below command

cf push

Once the app is deployed navigate to the cloud foundry -> your space -> your app, get the application routes url for testing.

Use,

  • application_routes_url/   
  • application_routes_url/fetch_data 
  • application_routes_url/update_data

Test results

Home page

                          Fig 28. Home page

Fetch Data

                                      Fig 29. Fetch data via OData

Conclusion

Integrating SAP BTP with SAP S/4HANA Cloud using the Destination Service and SAP Cloud Connector provides a secure and scalable way to extend your enterprise systems into the cloud. In this blog, we explored how to configure the necessary services, set up destinations, and connect a cloud application to S/4HANA Cloud to fetch and modify Purchase Order data using OData APIs.

Whether you're building a full-stack application or a lightweight service to automate business processes, understanding the role of Destination Service and Cloud Connector is critical to securely bridging the gap between your cloud apps and backend systems. This approach not only enhances flexibility but also ensures your architecture stays modular, maintainable, and cloud-ready.

I hope this blog serves as a helpful starting point for anyone new to SAP BTP and Destination service. Stay tuned for more hands-on insights and real-world examples from my journey with agentic use cases and enterprise integration!

entry.title: ​A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Chapter 1: Define the Purpose 

This guide helps Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition partners and customers to build custom mobile applications by integrating the Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) with SAP Build Code-Mobile Develop Kit (MDK). To demonstrate seamless warehouse task management, we have created a step-by-step guide blog for developing a demo mobile app. It should be noted that only advanced requirements need to be addressed by developing a custom app. In this context (Warehouse Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Mobile Warehousing ), we already have a standard RFUI app available for mobile devices.

Through this blog, you will learn: 

  • How to initiate the development of your mobile app project in SAP Build Code. 
  • How to quickly build the frontend using drag-and-drop UI components. 
  • How to trigger GET requests to retrieve warehouse tasks using no-code methods and additional JS code. 
  • How to deploy and run the demo app on mobile devices. 

Prerequisites   
Before starting development, ensure you have configured: 

  1. An SAP BTP subaccount. 
  2. Access to SAP Build Code. 
  3. Create your server destination and fill in your server URL and authorization method. (example destination server URL :
    {{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001    )
  • Go to Connectivity > Destination section in BTP Cockpit. 

  • Enter your server configuration and "Save" your Service Destination. 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 2: Create a New Mobile Project    

1. In SAP Build Code Lobby, click "Create" -> "Create" to start the creation process. 

 

 

 2. Select "Application" and click "Next". 

 3. Choose "Mobile" and click "Next". 

 4. Choose "Mobile Application" and click "Next". 

5. Enter the Project Name as desired, select a Dev Space, and then click "Review". 

 6. Click "Create". 

 7. Wait until the project is created and click the project name to enter the web development studio. 

 

 

Chapter 3: Configure the Storyboard 

There are three types of settings that must be configured in the storyboard: 

  • Runtime Resources: View the mobile services application and mobile destination used in the project. 
  • External Resources: View the external services used in the project (including the OData data structure if utilized). 
  • UI Applications: View the mobile applications. 

1. Click any "+" button in the Runtime Resources section to add a mobile services app to your project. (You may need to log in if your Cloud Foundry login session has expired.) 

2. You can choose from the existing services list, or click the "+" button to create a new mobile services app configuration. 

 

 
To create a new service, name your app and the app ID as desired on the Basic Information page, then click "Next". 

 

3. On the Destination page, select SAP Destination Service as the Destination type. Then click "Create App". 

Ensure that Cloud Destination has been configured in the Prerequisites (which uses the Server URL via the WOWT API: Warehouse Order and Task (A2X) - Overview | Warehouse Order and Task (A2X) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub 
 

Select the Server in your checkbox and click "Add App to Project". 

 

 

 4. Design and implement a user interface application. Click "+" button in UI Application. 

 

 5. Choose a template type (choosing any templates has no impact on this demo but it can accelerate the development) and click "Next". 

In "Select Service Type", choose REST, then click "Finish". (Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API  also form an OData service. You can also choose OData here, but this tutorial focuses on teaching how to send API requests. For more detailed OData operations, you can refer to the materials in the reference.)

 

 

Chapter 4: Integration REST Request Without Writing Code 

Then we will create a simple showcase to demonstrate the WOWT API's usage in SAP Build Code. This demo includes a basic screen with some UI components to send a "Get Warehouse Task" request to the server. The returned warehouse tasks will be displayed accordingly. Please ensure all prerequisite steps are completed before this chapter.  

For more detail about this request, please check the help document for WOWT API:Help Document For Warehouse Order and Task (A2X) 

Here is the example RESTful service request URL in this guide: 
{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/warehousetask 

As outlined in the prerequisites, we have already set the destination server URL to: 
{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001 

1. In the left explorer panel, find the "Pages" folder, open it, then double click "Main.page". 

 

 2. Search for "Object Table" in the components list under “Controls” on the left. And drag it to the primary interface. 

 3. Select the object table you just dragged onto the interface; there is a "properties setting" on its right side. In the properties setting of the object table, you need: 

- Select the REST Service Target  

- Select the service in "Service"(set in the previous chapter) 

- Enter the service address '/warehousetask ' of the WOWT API in "Path". 

- Set the "OutputPath" property value to '/value'. 

- Check the "Request Properties"- "Method" is GET (Default) 

The final settings should be as shown in the figure below. 

Service is your destination URL set before in this case: 
Path: property value is your corresponding RESTful request URL. 
OutputPath: property value is set to '/value'. This means that you only want the return data in 'value'. 
Example returns data as follows; we only want data in the 'value' path. 

4. Scroll down the properties setting of the object table, you need:           

- Find the input box named "Title" and enter ' wt:{WarehouseTask} ' 

- Find the input box named "Description" and enter ' {Product} ' 

- Find the input box named "StatusText" and enter ' wh:{EWMWarehouse} ' 

- Find the input box named "Subhead" and enter ' wo: {WarehouseOrder} ' 

 
In this demo, we display WarehouseOrder, WarehouseTask, Product and EWMWarehouse in the Object Table. You can also select the specific data you want to display and write it in the corresponding position of the Object Table Properties using the format {EntityName}. 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 5: Implement Using JavaScript Code (Advanced) 

If the provided basic methods fail to meet advanced requirements, built-in code can also be used for further customization. In this chapter, JavaScript code is employed to send the same "Get Warehouse Task" request with the code bound to a button. When triggered by a user click, the retrieved data will be displayed directly via an alert. For simplicity, the code here only displays raw data, but you can implement more complex logic during actual development. 

 

1. Create a new Rule by right clicking the Rules folder and selecting "MDK: New Rules". 

 

 2. Choose the "Empty JS Rule" and click "Next". 

 3. Enter the name "getWT" for the new JS Rule and click "Finish". Then, copy the following JS code into the generated "getWT.action" file.  

Code: 

export default function sendRequest(clientAPI) { 

// Replace {your_service_name} with your actual server’s name 

  const path = '/{your_service_name}/WarehouseTask?$top=1';  

  const params = { 

    'method': 'GET' 

  }; 

    

  return clientAPI.sendRequest(path, params).then(result => { 

    alert(result.content.toString()); 

  }); 

}

 

You need to replace {your_service_name} with the service name you are using. Your service name is the filename of the ".server" configuration file in the "Services" folder. 

4. Add a button to Main.page. 

5. Click on the button you added. There is a "properties setting" and "event" on its right side, click "Event", then bind the "Handler" to the "getWT" rule. 

 

 

Chapter 6: Deploy the Demo to Mobile 

1. Open the Application.app file, click the "Deploy" option in the editor's header area, and then choose the deployment target as “Mobile Services”. 

2. Select deploy target as "Mobile Services". (Cloud Web apps may not be suitable for RESTful services) 

If you want to enable source for debugging the deployed bundle, then choose "Yes". 

You should see "Deployed to Mobile Services successfully!" and current revision time. Ignore the other error messages in "PROBLEMS ". 

 

 

Chapter 7: Run the Demo on Mobile 

Using "Mobile Svcs" (download in app store) scan this QRcode and logon to run the latest version of your mobile app. 

Choose "Deploy" to generate QR code. 

The On-boarding QR code is now displayed. 

You must log in to your BTP account, and set a separate password for the mobile app. 

 

 

Chapter 8: Demo Real-Device Display Screenshots (Running on iPhone) 

After successfully launching the application, you will be able to view the object table created in Chapter 5, with its content automatically populated by the EWM warehouse, warehouse task, warehouse order, and product data retrieved from the request. 

Click the "button", and you will see an alert pop up displaying the raw data returned from the request, as shown in the figure below. 

 

 

 

 

Conclusion   

Building custom mobile apps for Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition doesn’t have to be a complex coding marathon with SAP Build Code, you can streamline warehouse management workflows by seamlessly integrating the WOWT API, leveraging no-code tools for rapid prototyping, and enhancing functionality with JavaScript for advanced use cases. This guide can equip you to deliver robust mobile solutions—from initial setup to deployment—with confidence. 

Ready to build your own app?   

Start with the step-by-step guide and explore the SAP Build Code platform. Share your feedback or questions below—we’d love to hear how you’re innovating in warehouse management! 🚀 

 

 

Referenced Data and Additional Training Lessons 

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API 
Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) 

 

Official tutorial web for mobile development kit clients. 

SAP Tutorial Navigator | Tutorials for SAP Developers 

 

Explore the mobile development kit SDK and build a custom Android/iOS client, enable push notifications, and create extensions. 

Brand Your Customized App with Mobile Development Kit SDK | SAP Tutorials 

 

Customize the look and feel of your MDK app with extension controls using metadata approach or Native script plugins. 

Create Extension Controls in Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Apps | SAP Tutorials 

 

Increase your understanding of the mobile development kit, learn how to create, delete a record, how to display the data from the related entity, and how to upload client logs to mobile services. 

Enhance Your First MDK App with Additional Functionalities | SAP Tutorials 

 

Become proficient with the mobile development kit by learning how to handle an error archive, add styling, deep link, and leverage OData annotations. 

Level Up with the Mobile Development Kit | SAP Tutorials 

 

Use the SAP Mobile Services mobile development kit (MDK) to create your first multi-channel (mobile and web) application, connect to an OData backend, and use MDK controls to enhance it.  

Create Your First MDK Application | SAP Tutorials 

 

Help document for Metadata reference.

entry.title: ​Advanced Developing Skills to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management
entry.content:
Chapter 1: Define the Purpose 

This guide helps Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition partners and customers to build custom mobile applications by integrating the Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) with SAP Build Code. 

Previously, we published a step-by-step guide blog detailing the development process for a sample mobile application.
（A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code：https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800）

This follow-up article will highlight key features and advantages of the SAP Build Code-Mobile Develop Kit that enhance development, including: 

  • Use the built-in "Actions" to quickly generate a REST request. 
  • Debugging methods for mobile applications. 
  • Joule AI co-development, with examples of automated code assistance to accelerate the development process. 

 

Chapter 2: Use Actions with JavaScript 

This chapter introduces key points for using Actions to create and send a REST request. Actions are a set of built-in instructions in SAP Build Code. They enable you to control mobile application behaviors such as navigation, messaging, document opening, and other behaviors using visual no-code or low-code methods. Additionally, they support generating instructions for sending requests via REST services. For a detailed tutorial, you can refer to this guide. 

SendRequest - Mobile Development Kit References 
Step to create a REST Action: 

1.Right-click the Actions folder in the file directory of the project and select "MDK: New Action". 

 2. Choose "REST Service Send Request" and click "Next". 

 3. You can configure your service URL and additional properties here. "Success Action" and "Failure Action" refer to the actions to be taken after the request succeeds or fails, respectively. 

 4. The obtained result can be retrieved via actionBinding, and further operations can be performed on it. 
Using example in previous Blog: （A Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code：https://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800）

Set the "Target" of the action to the rest request for getting warehousetask： 

{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001 

Then the returned warehousetask information will be as shown in the figure below.  

 

Next, we can create a Rule use the following example code. 

Example code: 

export default function ShowWarehouseTask(clientAPI) { 

  alert(JSON.stringify(clientAPI.getActionBinding())); 

}

Last step, bind the "Success Action" of the send request action to this rule file. This means that if the request returns a success, this successful rule will be triggered. We can then bind this action to the button on the page and click it to trigger it (for specific methods, refer to the previous blog).

 

 

Chapter 3: Tracing API Request in Mobile App 

For tracing request and returned information sent in mobile app. 

1. Open the mobile service on the storyboard, which can be found in Quick Access. 

 2. Scroll down to the bottom of the "Add on Features" section. If the "Network Trace" option is not visible, click the nearby "Add Feature" button to enable it. 

 3. After clicking ​​"Start Recording"​​, use the mobile app to send requests. The log will capture all network requests. After downloading the ​​recording​​, view the request status, response values, and other details ​​to analyze the issue​​. 

 

 

Chapter 4: Joule Example: Using Joule AI to Accelerate Development 

Joule AI integrated into this web-based compiler enhances rapid development. 

However, ​​for complex actions​​, its generated code may lack precision or executability, requiring manual inspection and refinement. ​​For simpler actions and UIs​​, Joule significantly accelerates development—​​the clearer your language descriptions​​, ​​the more tailored content Joule generates​​. 

​​Key commonly used commands include:​ 

1. /mdk-gen-action 
Automatically generates action configurations and embeds them into mobile service files. These actions can be bound to UI elements (e.g., buttons) to trigger workflows—such as navigation, message prompts, or REST API calls (e.g., GET/POST). 

2. /mdk-gen-page 
Generates UI pages based on OData entity metadata or custom requirements. 

You may also use /help to discover other available features.  

 

​Usage Example​​: Taking the use of the Cancel Warehouse Task Request in the WOWT API as an example, we need to use the Joule function to generate action code and UI interfaces. 

Input in Joule： 

"I need a 'send request' action to send a POST request to:   

{{starturl}}/sap/opu/odata4/.../WarehouseTask(   

  EWMWarehouse='{{whse}}',   

  WarehouseTask='{{wt}}',   

  WarehouseTaskItem='{{wt_item}}'   

)/SAP__self.CancelWarehouseTask?sap-client={{client}}   

Headers:   

- If-Match: *   

- X-CSRF-Token: {{csrf_token}}"

 

For UI Creation: 

/mdk-gen-page #your_service  

"Generate a form page with:   

Text input fields for:   

   - Warehouse Task ID   

   - Warehouse Item ID   

   - Warehouse Location   

A confirmation button labeled 'Cancel Task'"

Output: 

Next, you only need to make simple modifications to quickly generate a cancel warehouse task request page. 

 

 

Conclusion   

This guide introduces some advanced usage methods of SAP Build Code as well as distinctive tools that are different from those in other development approaches, etc. The main content includes: 

  • Using built-in tools "Actions" to simplify REST API integration. 
  • Debugging network requests directly in the app. 
  • Leveraging Joule AI to speed up basic code and UI creation. 

It is hoped that these advanced methods can be helpful to you when developing mobile apps for our API in Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

 

Referenced Data and Additional Training Lessons 

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API 
Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub)

SAP Tutorial Navigator | Tutorials for SAP Developers 

 

Explore the mobile development kit SDK and build a custom Android/iOS client, enable push notifications, and create extensions. 

Brand Your Customized App with Mobile Development Kit SDK | SAP Tutorials 

 

Customize the look and feel of your MDK app with extension controls using metadata approach or Native script plugins. 

Create Extension Controls in Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Apps | SAP Tutorials 

 

Increase your understanding of the mobile development kit, learn how to create, delete a record, how to display the data from the related entity, and how to upload client logs to mobile services. 

Enhance Your First MDK App with Additional Functionalities | SAP Tutorials 

 

Become proficient with the mobile development kit by learning how to handle an error archive, add styling, deep link, and leverage OData annotations. 

Level Up with the Mobile Development Kit | SAP Tutorials 

 

Use the SAP Mobile Services mobile development kit (MDK) to create your first multi-channel (mobile and web) application, connect to an OData backend, and use MDK controls to enhance it.

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is “clean core”?

Let’s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: An SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called “clean core extensibility”. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, as the Public Cloud Edition cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the public cloud, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model – Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP S/4HANA, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core—decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability—remain essential.

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP S/4HANA system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP S/4HANA, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP S/4HANA

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes – all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP’s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP S/4HANA.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP’s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP S/4HANA and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you’re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

For ABAP-based extensibility for clean core see the ABAP Extensibility Guide.

Finally, we have a learning journey for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
A few months ago, we shared our excitement about the launch of the first-ever SAP BTP Hackathon in Africa in joined collaboration of AFSUG and SAP, highlighting the unique opportunity it offered for AFSUG members to bring their creativity and problem-solving skills to the forefront of the SAP community. Now, with the event behind us, it’s time to reflect on what unfolded and celebrate the teams and ideas that made this inaugural Hackathon truly special.

From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration

As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Unlock SAP Joule for Developers—Claim Your Free Access Today
entry.content:
Try SAP Joule for Developers—Now Available for Free 

We have recently introduced powerful new Joule capabilities for developers across SAP Build Code, SAP Build Process Automation, SAP Build Apps, and ABAP environment. These AI features are designed to accelerate development, boost productivity, and bring intelligence into the tools you already use. 

Now’s the perfect time to try them. SAP Joule for Developers is available for free through the end of Q3 2026. Once the free offer ends, a commercial model based on AI Units will apply—so don’t miss this opportunity to explore what’s possible with AI in your SAP development tools. 

 Quick reminder: A valid license for SAP Build or ABAP is required to use the AI capabilities in those environments. 

 

What is SAP Joule for Developers? 

Announced on March 18, SAP Joule for Developers is a package of embedded AI capabilities powered by Joule and available within: 

  • SAP Build Code 
  • SAP Build Process Automation 
  • SAP Build Apps 
  • ABAP Environment 

These tools now help you generate code from natural language, automate processes faster, and build apps more efficiently—all with AI integrated directly into the experience. 

We’ll walk through the setup steps in an upcoming section. But first, here are some helpful resources to catch up on the latest: 

  • Read the Announcement
  • Explore the Technical Overview
  • Check out the FAQs

 

Customer Success

See how early adopters are already transforming their work with SAP Joule for Developers: 

“Joule for Developers dramatically boosts productivity by enabling developers to quickly generate enterprise-grade apps, including logic, data models, sample data, and test scripts. It serves as a virtual guide to assist developers during design-time and helps resolve local testing exceptions efficiently.” — Gerard Van Paassen, CEO at Aarini Consulting 

“Joule for Developers not only generates data models but also makes it simple to design Fiori UIs and enrich test data—resulting in a major productivity boost across our development lifecycle.” — Michael Brand, Senior Consultant at FIS 

“PwC uses Joule for Developers in SAP Build to rapidly deliver innovative SAP solutions. Its generative AI supercharges our developers’ output, helping us accelerate award-winning ESG solutions while extending SAP S/4HANA and other enterprise apps—without compromising the clean core.” — Dr. Nicholas Nicoloudis, Global Head of SAP Innovation at PwC 

From accelerating application generation to streamlining code optimization, customers are seeing measurable time savings, higher productivity, and better quality in their SAP extension development projects. 

Stay tuned as we share more customer experiences—yours could be next. Try SAP Joule for Developers today while it’s free. 

 

Activate AI capabilities in SAP Build: 

Now, let’s walk through how to enable the AI capabilities in SAP Build. 

Note: AI capabilities in SAP Build Code have already been enabled and available for use in the environment. The instructions below applies to SAP Build Process Automation and SAP Build Apps. 

1. On the Build homepage, click Control Tower in the left-hand navigation panel. 

 2. Select Generative AI from the settings canvas. 

 3. Toggle the Enable Generative AI button 

 4. Read and accept the SAP AI Terms 

 5. Verify that the AI features are enabled 

 

 

Activate AI capabilities in ABAP Environment: 

 

A. For Customers: 

1. Contact your Account Executive to purchase the SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities license (SKU ID: 8019124). The AE will create an order containing the license material. 

2. Once the purchase is complete, ABAP development systems will be enabled for ABAP AI capabilities within 48 hours. 

3. To start using Joule capabilities in ABAP, ensure you have the required authorizations. For details, see the documentation and screenshot below.

 

B. For Partners: 

1. Get the TDD ABAP AI capabilities license (SKU ID 8019541):  

  • Go to Manage My Services App 
  • Add the SKU to an existing order, e.g. Pay-as-you-go (see screenshots below). 

2. Once the purchase is complete, ABAP development systems will be enabled for ABAP AI capabilities within 48 hours. 

3. To start using Joule capabilities in ABAP, ensure you have the required authorizations. For details, see the documentation and screenshot below.

 

Start leveraging the power of AI today!  

Enable SAP Joule for Developers and experience a significant boost in your development efficiency. Don't miss out on the free offer! 

 #SAPJouleForDevelopers #SAPBuild #ABAPCloud #SAPBusinessTechnologyPlatform
